evidence.dc:description:
Western blot on human heart tissue (interventricular septum) from 6 patients with HOCM (myectomy) showed an increase in skeletal muscle α-actin compared to 4 control donor hearts.

This study also showed that thin filaments containing actin that were isolated from normal and HOCM heart muscle were indistinguishable when subjected to an in vitro motility assay.

dc:source.dc:abstract: We have developed a quantitative antibody-based assay to measure the content of skeletal muscle alpha-actin relative to cardiac alpha-actin. We found 21 +/- 2% skeletal muscle alpha-actin content in normal heart muscle of adult man and mouse. In end stage failing heart 53 +/- 5% of striated actin was skeletal muscle alpha-actin and in samples of inter-ventricular septum from patients with hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM) skeletal muscle alpha-actin was 72 +/- 2% of sarcomeric actin. Thin filaments containing actin isolated from normal and HOCM heart muscle were functionally indistinguishable when studied by quantitative in vitro motility assay. We also found elevated skeletal muscle alpha-actin (60 +/- 7%) in a mouse model of dilated cardiomyopathy.
dc:source.dc:creator: Copeland O
dc:source.dc:title: Investigation of changes in skeletal muscle alpha-actin expression in normal and pathological human and mouse hearts.

evidence.rdfs:label: Copeland 2010 Expression1

evidence.dc:description: RNA-seq on hearts from D2 mice (HCM strain) showed an upregulation of α1-actin compared to B6 mice (reference strain).

dc:source.dc:abstract: Familial hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) is attributed to mutations in genes that encode for the sarcomere proteins, especially Mybpc3 and Myh7. Genotype-phenotype correlation studies show significant variability in HCM phenotypes among affected individuals with identical causal mutations. Morphological changes and clinical expression of HCM are the result of interactions with modifier genes. With the exceptions of angiotensin converting enzyme, these modifiers have not been identified. Although mouse models have been used to investigate the genetics of many complex diseases, natural murine models for HCM are still lacking. In this study we show that the DBA/2J (D2) strain of mouse has sequence variants in Mybpc3 and Myh7, relative to widely used C57BL/6J (B6) reference strain and the key features of human HCM. Four-month-old of male D2 mice exhibit hallmarks of HCM including increased heart weight and cardiomyocyte size relative to B6 mice, as well as elevated markers for cardiac hypertrophy including β-myosin heavy chain (MHC), atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP), brain natriuretic peptide (BNP), and skeletal muscle alpha actin (α1-actin). Furthermore, cardiac interstitial fibrosis, another feature of HCM, is also evident in the D2 strain, and is accompanied by up-regulation of type I collagen and α-smooth muscle actin (SMA)-markers of fibrosis. Of great interest, blood pressure and cardiac function are within the normal range in the D2 strain, demonstrating that cardiac hypertrophy and fibrosis are not secondary to hypertension, myocardial infarction, or heart failure. Because D2 and B6 strains have been used to generate a large family of recombinant inbred strains, the BXD cohort, the D2 model can be effectively exploited for in-depth genetic analysis of HCM susceptibility and modifier screens.
dc:source.dc:creator: Zhao W
dc:source.dc:title: A Murine Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy Model: The DBA/2J Strain.

evidence.rdfs:label: Zhao 2015 Expression1

evidence.dc:description: The study focuses on characterizing the D2 strain as a promising model for HCM and there are no other papers validating this yet. 0 points assigned since other studies confirm upregulation in humans (see Lim, 2001).

Left ventricular septal tissue obtained by myomectomy of HCM patient and a corresponding segment was taken from an age- and gender- matched normal donor heart.

Subtraction hybridization between mRNA pools extracted from normal heart and HCM heart showed an upregulation of ACTA1 in the HCM heart, which was confirmed by Northern blot. Upregulation was further confirmed in six additional HCM hearts.

dc:source.dc:abstract: The goal of this study was to identify genes upregulated in the heart in human patients with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM).
dc:source.dc:creator: Lim DS
dc:source.dc:title: Expression profiling of cardiac genes in human hypertrophic cardiomyopathy: insight into the pathogenesis of phenotypes.

evidence.rdfs:label: Lim 2001 Expression1

evidence.dc:description: K336E mutant showed decreased binding affinity for α-actinin compared to wild type. ACTN2 has a moderate association with HCM.

dc:source.dc:abstract: We report on a 2-year-old male child with both nemaline myopathy and hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM). Sequencing of the ACTA1 gene showed a "de novo" missense heterozygous mutation a>g in exon 7 (Lys336Glu). Two-dimensional electrophoresis showed 28% mutant actin present in his muscle biopsy. Actin was isolated from the muscle biopsy and examined by in vitro motility assay. The sliding speed was 13+/-3% less than normal and the affinity of actin for the Z-line protein alpha-actinin was reduced 10 fold. This is the first report on a hypertrophic cardiomyopathy associated with nemaline myopathy and an ACTA1 mutation.
dc:source.dc:creator: D'Amico A
dc:source.dc:title: Fatal hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and nemaline myopathy associated with ACTA1 K336E mutation.

evidence.rdfs:label: D'Amico 2006 P.I.1

evidence.detectionMethod: All 6 protein encoding exons of ACTA1 were sequenced in patient II:2. Exon 7 sequenced in family members. Variant not found in 50 control individuals.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Diagnosed with central core disease in infancy.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Mutations in 3 core disease loci RYR1, MYH7, and SEPN1 ruled out.

dc:source.dc:creator: Kaindl AM
dc:source.dc:title: Missense mutations of ACTA1 cause dominant congenital myopathy with cores.

evidence.rdfs:label: Kaindl 2004 II:2

evidence.dc:description: No other testing to determine whether mutation was present in known HCM genes. Reported as p.E334A but really p.K336E?

evidence.detectionMethod: Variant found by direct sequencing of genomic DNA.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: nemaline myopathy, RVOT obstruction, max wall thickness RV = 6.5mm, elevated serum creatine kinase

dc:source.dc:abstract: A twenty-year old male presented with diffuse limb muscle weakness and exertional dyspnea since childhood. The diagnosis of nemaline myopathy was given based on the muscle pathology findings that revealed nemaline rods on light and electron microscopy and discovery of a novel mutation, E239K, in ACTA1. Incidentally, the patient had hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) as shown by echocardiography. In nemaline myopathy, a few cases of HCM have been reported, albeit rarely and always fatal, but only one patient had ACTA1 mutation. This present report describes an infantile onset of nemaline myopathy with a milder clinical course and non-fatal HCM as compared with previous cases, showing clinical diversity in skeletal and cardiac manifestations of conditions associated with ACTA1 mutations.
dc:source.dc:creator: Kim SY
dc:source.dc:title: Nemaline myopathy and non-fatal hypertrophic cardiomyopathy caused by a novel ACTA1 E239K mutation.

evidence.rdfs:label: Kim 2011 Case1

evidence.dc:description: Parents negative for variant. Mutation not found in 200 normal control chromosomes. No other testing to determine whether mutation was present in known HCM genes. 0 points since this patient has nemaline myopathy.

evidence.detectionMethod: Genomic sequencing of ACTA1 identified mutation. Not present in peripheral blood DNA of either parent.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Nemaline myopathy, Hypotonia, heart murmur, MWT (IVS) = 6.7mm, died suddenly at 3 years
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Mutations of ACTC and TPM3 were ruled out.
evidence.rdfs:label: D'Amico 2006 Case1

evidence.dc:description: Actin was isolated from muscle biopsy and 2D electrophoresis revealed 28% mutant actin. Affinity of acttin for the Z-line alpha-actinin was reduced 10 fold. No other testing to determine whether mutation was present in known HCM genes. This is the first report on HCM associated with nemaline myopathy and ACTA1 mutation.

dc:description:
ACTA1 was first reported in relation to autosomal dominant hypertrophic cardiomyopathy in 2001 (Lim et al., PMID: 11583900). Summary of case level and experimental data: 1.5 points. Only 3 cases of HCM have been reported: 2 of the cases were in patients with nemaline myopathy and the third case was in a patient with congenital myopathy with cores. Therefore, there is no genetic evidence fo HCM alone. Evidence supporting this gene-disease relationship includes  expression data showing altered gene expression in patients, and functional assays showing variants in ACTA1 result in decreased binding affinity for α-actinin compared to wild type. No convincing evidence for a causal role for ACTA1 in autosomal dominant hypertrophic cardiomyopathy has been reported. Although this gene-disease association is supported by the aforementioned expression studies and functional assays, no reports
have directly implicated the gene in humans.
